movie_profile.title: The 400 Blows
movie_profile.overview: For young Parisian boy Antoine Doinel, life is one difficult situation after another. Surrounded by inconsiderate adults, including his neglectful parents, Antoine spends his days with his best friend, Rene, trying to plan for a better life. When one of their schemes goes awry, Antoine ends up in trouble with the law, leading to even more conflicts with unsympathetic authority figures.

movie_profile.title: Ricco
movie_profile.overview: Fresh out of the joint, young Ricco is eager to get home to see his family. He was cut loose a year early for good behavior, but it certainly wasn't good behavior that got him in the big house in the first place. Two years prior, Ricco took it upon himself to go after Don Avito, the man who killed his pappy and took his girlfriend. Yet Ricco came out of prison a changed man. He had a lot of time to think, and the anger and thirst for revenge is no longer there, much to his mother's chagrin. She is quite upset that her son is not interested in paying back Don Avito for his deeds, and she needles Ricco relentlessly until he reluctantly gives in to her demands.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

critic_outputs.rationale: Ricco’s arc—from renouncing vengeance to being pressured by his mother—promises emotionally grounded conflict and psychological complexity you tend to value. It’s an action‑driven foreign revenge story that fits your openness to genre variety (e.g., The Defender) and foreign films (The Way Home), though its tone may be heavier than your usual lighthearted favorites.

Ricco’s tension between rehabilitation and being pushed back into revenge touches real-world issues of post-prison change and family pressure, aligning with your empathetic, character-focused interests. Your 5.0 for The Defender suggests you can enjoy action, and your arthouse nights hint you’re open to Foreign films. Still, the revenge-driven action may feel heavier than your usual lighthearted picks.

judge_outputs.justification: Both critics connect Ricco’s character conflict to the user’s empathetic tastes, but each includes unsupported claims: critic 1 asserts a renunciation arc and mother-driven pressure not evidenced in Ricco’s known plot and cites film-history references (The Defender/The Way Home) not in context; critic 2 references a 5.0 for The Defender and implies family pressure without support. I favored the more moderate 3.5 (critic 2) due to caution and fewer specific inaccuracies, down-weighted the higher 4.0 given tonal mismatch with the user’s lighthearted lean, and penalized both for unsupported claims.

movie_profile.title: Guy
movie_profile.overview: A young, female filmmaker looks through her camera for an object to film. She wants to film the private live of an ordinary person and starts following Guy. He is very irritated about this girl following him, always looking through her camera, never showing herself. She does not even say her name but follows him even home to his bedroom. He tries to get rid of her but she does not stop. After a while he gets used to the camera and the girl behind it and tries to get involved with her. First she protects herself with her camera but cannot keep the barrier up. When their feelings and Guy's actions become too confusing for them Guy disappears mysteriously.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

movie_profile.title: Deep Impact
movie_profile.overview: A seven-mile-wide space rock is hurtling toward Earth, threatening to obliterate the planet. Now, it's up to the president of the United States to save the world. He appoints a tough-as-nails veteran astronaut to lead a joint American-Russian crew into space to destroy the comet before impact. Meanwhile, an enterprising reporter uses her smarts to uncover the scoop of the century.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

movie_profile.title: How to Murder Your Wife
movie_profile.overview: Stanley Ford leads an idyllic bachelor life. He is a nationally syndicated cartoonist whose Bash Brannigan series provides him with a luxury townhouse and a full-time valet, Charles. When he wakes up the morning after the night before - he had attended a friend's stag party - he finds that he is married to the very beautiful woman who popped out of the cake - and who doesn't speak a word of English. Despite his initial protestations, he comes to like married life and even changes his cartoon character from a super spy to a somewhat harried husband.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

movie_profile.title: Ricco
movie_profile.overview: Fresh out of the joint, young Ricco is eager to get home to see his family. He was cut loose a year early for good behavior, but it certainly wasn't good behavior that got him in the big house in the first place. Two years prior, Ricco took it upon himself to go after Don Avito, the man who killed his pappy and took his girlfriend. Yet Ricco came out of prison a changed man. He had a lot of time to think, and the anger and thirst for revenge is no longer there, much to his mother's chagrin. She is quite upset that her son is not interested in paying back Don Avito for his deeds, and she needles Ricco relentlessly until he reluctantly gives in to her demands.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

critic_outputs.rationale: Ricco’s action-forward, revenge-driven plot may clash with your lighthearted, comedy-leaning tastes, but the post-prison change-of-heart and mother–son tension add character focus you tend to appreciate. Your 5.0 for The Defender and comfort with foreign films suggest you could still find this engaging, if not a favorite.

Its revenge setup wrapped in a son–mother dynamic offers some character conflict your empathetic side may appreciate. But as an Action/Foreign, vendetta-driven piece aligned with martial-arts/crime neighbors, it’s likely lighter on the comedy and warmth you favor, even if your openness to genre (e.g., The Defender) suggests some appeal.

judge_outputs.justification: Both critics provide moderate, consistent 3.5 scores and reasonable genre-based fit, but they include unverified specifics (revenge/post-prison arc, mother–son tension) and reference a 5.0 for The Defender/foreign-film comfort not in the given context, so both are flagged. With similar confidence and balanced tones, weights are equal, yielding r_tilde=3.5.

movie_profile.title: This Island Earth
movie_profile.overview: Aliens have landed and are hiding on Earth, but need Earth’s scientists to help them fight an inter-planetary war.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

critic_outputs.rationale: Your history shows you enjoy sci‑fi/horror alongside quirky fare (Tron, Freaks, The Slumber Party Massacre), so this mystery–adventure about aliens recruiting Earth scientists aligns with those tastes. However, the premise doesn’t signal a woman-centered or subversive angle nor a lighthearted, character-driven focus, which may temper enthusiasm. Nearest neighbors like The X Files and In the Mouth of Madness suggest a decent but not perfect fit.

Genre overlap with the user’s sci-fi/horror/mystery leanings (e.g., Tron, Freaks, Dead Man’s Folly) and the nearest neighbors suggests a decent fit. But the overview signals plot-driven interplanetary-war stakes over character-focused comedy/drama, and there’s no evidence here of standout technical craft, so enthusiasm may be moderate.

judge_outputs.justification: Both critics provide factually supported rationales about the film’s sci‑fi/horror fit and plot‑driven tone; no unsupported claims. Weights are confidence‑proportional with a slight tilt to the more confident feminist_critic, whose focus on character/lighthearted mismatch is relevant to the user’s profile. Resulting calibrated score is a balanced 3.5.

movie_profile.title: Is the Man Who Is Tall Happy?
movie_profile.overview: A series of interviews featuring linguist, philosopher and activist Noam Chomsky done in hand-drawn animation.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

critic_outputs.rationale: Your arthouse lean and character-focused taste align with a hand-drawn, interview-based animated documentary. However, it centers a single male intellectual (Chomsky) with no sign of women’s perspectives, limiting female representation even as its activist slant engages power structures. Given your eclectic favorites and doc-adjacent neighbors, you may still appreciate its reflective approach.

An animated interview with Noam Chomsky promises socially engaged, idea-driven conversation and distinctive hand-drawn visuals that fit your arthouse and journaling leanings. However, its documentary-interview form may feel less character-focused and lighthearted than your usual drama/comedies.

judge_outputs.justification: Both critics converge on a mid-high fit (3.5). We slightly upweight the social_commentator for a well-supported, accurate read of the film’s form and tone. The feminist_critic is penalized for an overbroad claim (“no sign of women’s perspectives”) and referencing unspecified “doc-adjacent neighbors,” which isn’t supported by provided context.

movie_profile.title: Guy
movie_profile.overview: A young, female filmmaker looks through her camera for an object to film. She wants to film the private live of an ordinary person and starts following Guy. He is very irritated about this girl following him, always looking through her camera, never showing herself. She does not even say her name but follows him even home to his bedroom. He tries to get rid of her but she does not stop. After a while he gets used to the camera and the girl behind it and tries to get involved with her. First she protects herself with her camera but cannot keep the barrier up. When their feelings and Guy's actions become too confusing for them Guy disappears mysteriously.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

critic_outputs.rationale: The film centers on an evolving, intimate push-pull between observer and subject, foregrounding psychology, boundaries, and emotional vulnerability—strong fits for your empathetic, character-focused, arthouse-leaning taste. Its ambiguous disappearance ending may limit satisfaction if you prefer levity or closure, but the character arc and ethical tension should be compelling.

The voyeuristic, intimate, character-driven premise aligns with this user's empathetic, character-focused, arthouse-leaning tastes. There's no indication of spectacle, star power, or mainstream crowd-pleasing beats in the overview, so it may not deliver blockbuster thrills but should still resonate.

judge_outputs.justification: Both align with the user’s character-focused, arthouse-leaning tastes. The first offers nuanced psychological/ethical fit but includes an unverified claim about an ambiguous disappearance ending (flagged), so its weight is trimmed. The second avoids unsupported specifics but largely echoes consensus; small groupthink penalty applied while keeping it slightly higher for reliability. Weighted average yields 4.0.

movie_profile.title: Street Kings
movie_profile.overview: Tom Ludlow is a disillusioned L.A. Police Officer, rarely playing by the rules and haunted by the death of his wife. When evidence implicates him in the execution of a fellow officer, he is forced to go up against the cop culture he's been a part of his entire career, ultimately leading him to question the loyalties of everyone around him.

context.user_personality: Drama / Comedy fan — empathetic, character-focused, lighthearted; age vibe: late 20s. Hobbies: arthouse nights, screenwriting pods, journaling.

critic_outputs.rationale: Its character-centered, disillusioned-cop drama aligns with your empathy-driven tastes and your 5-star enjoyment of action/crime like The Defender and Dead Man’s Folly. But it’s a serious action-crime thriller with minimal comedic relief, which may not satisfy your lighthearted, comedy-leaning side.

A hard-edged action/crime thriller about police corruption and grief offers character conflict and moral ambiguity you might appreciate, but little of the lighthearted tone you favor. The familiar cop-culture setup may feel conventional next to your quirkier, eclectic favorites.

judge_outputs.justification: Both note Street Kings is a gritty, serious cop-corruption thriller with limited levity, which fits the user’s empathy for character drama but clashes with their lighthearted/comedy lean. comedy_specialist is flagged for an unsupported claim about the user’s 5-star favorites, so their weight is reduced despite higher confidence. cinephile’s rationale is supported and relevant, thus weighted higher. The resulting score reflects a tempered recommendation in the low-to-mid 3s.
